Prototype Engineer at Sirius XM Radio Inc.
June 18, 2016, Khalid reported directly to Alex

It's a rare opportunity to work with someone like Alex. His perspective on building teams is unlike anyone I've ever met in a hiring position. I really wish I'd run into more people when interviewing that think and act like Alex. He never got stuck on the fact that I didn't have formal computer science background for a moment. He could care less, but was genuinely interested in what I had done so far, how I'd gotten there, where I wanted to go next and what motivated me. He never quizzed me with silly gotchas and was confident in me before even hiring me. It was very refreshing to not feel as if I was auditioning. At the time, Alex had already assembled a dream team (family) of engineers who'd been writing Objective-C decades before the iPhone's debut. I knew I was in the presence of greatness and was a bit intimidated, thinking I had no chance of joining the team. Alex eased my concerns and was very welcoming, complementing my achievements and ensuring I deserved to be there, just before making me an offer. I've never been so excited to join a team. Months later Alex made sure that I went to my first WWDC! The confidence in my own abilities he fostered, forever shaped my career. Every interaction was a pleasure and I would highly recommend Alex for any team. I hope that we can one day work together again.

I was much too young to fully appreciate Alex during the two years that I worked for him at Apple.  Only a few years into my career – I didn’t understand that Alex’s combination of genius, enthusiasm and drive to move a project forward against all odds was unique.  It was unclear that Alex’s constant effort to empower his team – pushing them to believe in themselves and love their jobs, to act boldly and trust their own judgment – was such a valuable and life-changing feature to find in a boss.  When working for Alex, every day was a challenge, there was a constant need to pick up a book or find a new site to learn new things, and an un-ending search for the next puzzle to solve.  In short – it was likely the best job I’ll ever have, and the benchmark against which all jobs (and bosses) since have been measured.
